Award.AwardTitle: Active Thermal Switching of Smart Composite Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Active Thermal Switching of "Smart" Composite Materials

All materials found in nature exhibit an ability to conduct heat defined by their thermal conductivity. Polymers, for example, have a low thermal conductivity, while metals typically possess a high thermal conductivity. This research explores the innovative concept of thermal switching wherein a smart material can be engineered such that its thermal conductivity can be actively controlled. Thermal switching is of interest for use in applications where control of thermal conductivity improves the functionality of a device or system. For example, heating and cooling in buildings, thermal storage, temperature adaptive textiles and thermal management of electronics or solar cells are all applications where intelligent control of heat transfer is required for next generation solutions. The objective of the research is to develop an innovative smart material with a thermal conductivity that can be switched either permanently or temporarily up to three orders of magnitude upon encountering a thermal stimulus. In other words, the material's thermal conductivity may be switched from behaving like a polymer to acting like a metal on demand. The material systems being developed consist of a shape memory polymer matrix and fiber-like fillers that have the ability to intelligently rearrange within the polymer.

The goal of this research is to develop an innovative smart material with a thermal conductivity that can be switched either permanently or temporarily by up to three orders of magnitude upon encountering a thermal stimulus with or without the presence of an additional external force. The material system comprises a shape memory polymer as the matrix to control the orientation of nanofiber fillers upon application of a stimulus. The following methods and approaches are being used: 1. Preparation of cellulose nanocrystal, boron nitride and carbon nanofibers. Fibers were chosen as the filler type because during the shape memory polymer contraction/expansion, a high aspect ratio filler is required in order to induce alignment. 2. Fabrication of nanofibers/shape memory polymer composites with the ability to achieve high thermal conductivities when fibers are "switched" into alignment and low thermal conductivities when fiber alignment is reduced. Two key classes of materials are being explored: semi-crystalline crosslinked polymers and cross-linked polymers with a glass transitions temperature above room temperature. In these materials the crystalline regions act as the thermal reversible transitions that fix the material in its strained temporary state. Upon increasing the temperature above the glass transition temperature, the material increases its elasticity, allowing to composite to be stretched and inducing alignment of the fibers. 3. Characterization of the composites to determine degree of dispersion and alignment of fillers using x-ray diffraction techniques. 4. Thermal characterization of the in-plane and through-thickness thermal conductivities of the composites and the axial thermal conductivity of the individual fibers. 5. Theoretical investigations into the thermal conductivity of the individual fibers and composite systems. 6. "Writing" of thermal conduction paths onto composite films and subsequent testing to demonstrate the effectiveness of the thermal switching at the device level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to develop an innovative ?smart? material with a thermal conductivity that could be ?switched? either permanently or temporarily by up to three orders of magnitude upon encountering a stimulus. The materials studied consisted of a shape memory polymer matrix and fiber-like fillers that have the ability to ?intelligently? rearrange within the polymer, resulting in a switch of the thermal conductivity.

 

The intellectual merit associated with this project encompasses the advancement of knowledge about thermal switching in materials, a phenomenon that has received only limited scientific attention. For this work, the selected shape-memory polymer was thermoplastic polyurethane (TPU). Its structure includes soft and hard phases that melt at different temperatures. Two classes of fiber-like fillers were investigated: cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs) and carbon nanofibers (CNFs). CNCs have moderate thermal conductivity (1-10 W/mK) and have been shown to disperse well in TPU. CNFs have high thermal conductivity (~1000 W/mK), but are prone to agglomeration due to their surface charge.

We demonstrated thermal switching in these materials via various experiments. TPU films alone that were repeatedly cycled through strained and relaxed states demonstrated that the thermal conductivity "switched" between ~0.15 W/m-K and ~0.5 W/m-K. Similar cyclic testing was done on composites comprised of tunicate-based CNCs in a TPU binder. The addition of highly-crystalline CNC fibers did raise the thermal conductivity of the composites (up to 1 W/m-K) and increased the switching ratio between the strained and relaxed states, but with a strong negative impact on the switching durability. For example, consistency in the switching response was lost after four cycles in composite samples strained to 100%. Nonetheless, Raman spectroscopy demonstrated that the cycling does lead to a change in alignment of the fibers, which influences the thermal conductivity. We found that aging can affect the embedded strain in the material, thereby negatively influencing the thermal conductivity and counteracting the enhancement. Therefore, other composite systems where aging may be less prominent could be used more reliably to achieve even larger switching ratios and higher thermal conductivities.

The broader impact of this project included advancing the discovery and development of thermally switchable materials for a wide variety of applications where improved and ?smart? thermal control may be required. For example, heating and cooling in buildings may be better facilitated by either blocking or enabling thermal conduction through the walls, depending on the interior vs. exterior conditions. Or, there are thermal storage applications for which either high or low thermal conduction is required depending on the need for heat in at a part-icular instant in time. And, the military has investigated temperature adaptive clothing to enable passive control for human thermoregulation. This project stepped us closer to finding solutions to achieve this level of control.

Even more, the project was accomplished while promoting the participation of undergraduate, graduate and high school students, including underrepresented groups, as well as the general public. In particular, our program provided enhanced learning opportunities through our public outreach opportunity: Discovery Day and our high school research program: Envoys. Additionally, several undergraduate and graduate students in mechanical engineering and polymer science collaborated and engaged in research projects associated with this award, enabling them to further pursue careers in science and engineering.
